senses.definition: the opportunity or right to use something or to see somebody/something

examples.x: High-speed internet access has become a necessity.
You need a password to get access to the computer system.
access to information/services/resources
access to healthcare/education
They are seeking increased access to markets overseas.
to provide/allow access to something/somebody
to restrict/block access to something/somebody
Journalists were denied access to the President.
Many divorced fathers only have access to their children at weekends (= they are allowed by law to see them only at weekends).

senses.definition: a way of entering or reaching a place

examples.x: The police gained access through a broken window.
Many paths have become overgrown, blocking access.
There is easy access by road.
We welcome disabled visitors and there is wheelchair access to all parts of the park.
The only access to the farmhouse is across the fields.

senses.definition: how easy something is to reach, enter, use, see, etc.

examples.x: Data accessibility and reliability are essential factors in today's business world.
Accessibility to computers is vital.
Improving the accessibility of woodlands to the public is seen as a key issue.

senses.definition: how easy something is to reach, enter, use, etc. for somebody with a disability

examples.x: The building has limited wheelchair accessibility.
This checklist will help you to evaluate the accessibility of a venue.

senses.definition: how easy something is to understand

examples.x: the accessibility of her poetry

senses.definition: the condition of not being able to recognize written words or letters, usually because of brain damage a-
a sign language (= a language that uses hand movements rather than words) developed and used in the US and also used in English-speaking parts of Canada

examples.x: Their daughter is deaf and they all use American Sign Language.
an American Sign Language interpreter

senses.definition: the loss of the ability to understand or produce speech, because of brain damage

a range of conditions affecting brain development that can be severe or mild, in which a person can find it difficult to communicate and form relationships, and may show repeated or limited patterns of thought and behaviour (the abbreviation for autism spectrum disorder)

examples.x: Many individuals with ASD find it challenging to navigate the social rules of dating.

senses.definition: a sign language (= a language that uses hand movements rather than words) developed and used in the US and also used in English-speaking parts of Canada (the abbreviation for American Sign Language)

examples.x: All our staff use ASL.
an ASL interpreter

senses.definition: an autism spectrum disorder (= one of a range of conditions affecting brain development and the ability to communicate or form relationships with others) that is less severe than some other forms
a dog trained to help somebody who has a medical condition or disability

examples.x: Dogs are not allowed inside the cafe, with the exception of assistance dogs.

senses.definition: accommodation for people who need help, for example with tasks like washing and dressing themselves

examples.x: assisted living apartments
assisted living and other options for elderly people

senses.definition: a condition affecting brain development that can be severe or mild. People with autism can find it difficult to communicate and form relationships, and may show repeated or limited patterns of thought and behaviour. -ism

a range of conditions affecting brain development that can be severe or mild, or any one of these conditions. People with autism spectrum disorder can find it difficult to communicate and form relationships, and may show repeated or limited patterns of thought and behaviour.

examples.x: support for families with children who have autism spectrum disorder
He was diagnosed with an autistic spectrum disorder.

senses.definition: having autism; connected with autism

examples.x: autistic children/traits
Our son is autistic.

senses.definition: not able to see

examples.x: Doctors think he will go blind.
She went blind at the age of ten.
blind and partially sighted people
One of her parents is blind.
She has been legally blind since birth.
The accident left me blind in one eye.

senses.definition: people who are blind the blind

examples.x: recorded books for the blind
guide dogs for the blind

senses.definition: not noticing or realizing something

examples.x: She is blind to her best friend's faults.
I must have been blind not to realize the danger we were in.
They seem to be totally blind to reality.
The government is not blind to the fact that the national debt is increasing.

senses.definition: seeming to be unreasonable, and accepted without question; seeming to be out of control

examples.x: blind faith/obedience
It was a moment of blind panic.

senses.definition: that cannot be controlled by reason

examples.x: blind chance
the blind force of nature

senses.definition: that a driver in a car cannot see, or cannot see around

examples.x: a blind driveway
a blind bend/corner

senses.definition: that does not make a difference between people on the basis of the quality mentioned, or favour one group over another

examples.x: In a piece of gender-blind casting, Hamlet is played by British actress Maxine Peake.
She is very suspicious of anyone who claims to be race-blind.

senses.definition: the condition of being unable to see

examples.x: total/temporary/partial blindness

senses.definition: the fact of not noticing or realizing something

examples.x: her blindness to the truth

senses.definition: a blue card with a picture of a wheelchair that can be displayed in the window of a car. It shows that somebody is recognized as having a disability and is allowed to park in certain places where other people may not park.
permanent damage to the brain caused by illness or an accident
a sign language (= a language that uses hand movements rather than words) developed and used in the UK

examples.x: She uses British Sign Language.
a British Sign Language interpreter

senses.definition: a sign language (= a language that uses hand movements rather than words) developed and used in the UK (the abbreviation for British Sign Language)

examples.x: She works with students who use BSL.
a BSL interpreter

senses.definition: a medical condition caused by a brain injury or development problem, usually before or at birth, that causes the loss of control of movement in the arms and legs
having captions that can only be read if you have a special machine (= a decoder)
unable to hear anything or unable to hear very well

examples.x: to become/go deaf
She was born deaf.
partially deaf

senses.definition: people who cannot hear the deaf

examples.x: television subtitles for the deaf

senses.definition: not willing to listen or pay attention to something

examples.x: He was deaf to my requests for help.
The committee remained deaf to our suggestions.

senses.definition: unable to hear and see anything or unable to hear and see very well

examples.x: Negotiating a public transport system presents all kinds of problems for people who are deaf-blind.

senses.definition: the condition of being unable to hear anything or unable to hear very well

examples.x: Measles can cause deafness and blindness.

senses.definition: the fact of not being willing to listen or pay attention to something

examples.x: his deafness to criticism

senses.definition: a physical or mental condition that makes it difficult for somebody to do some things that most other people can do

examples.x: a physical/developmental/intellectual disability
people with invisible disabilities such as hearing loss

senses.definition: the state of having a physical or mental condition that makes it difficult to do some things that most other people can do Disabled

examples.x: learning to live with disability
He qualifies for help on the grounds of disability.

senses.definition: having a condition that makes it difficult for you to do some things that most other people can do Disabled

examples.x: physically/developmentally/intellectually disabled
a new home for severely disabled people
My sister is learning disabled (= she has a learning disability).
temporarily/permanently disabled
The stroke left him disabled.
The museum has special facilities for disabled people.
Does the theatre have disabled access?

senses.definition: people who are disabled the disabled

examples.x: caring for the sick, elderly and disabled

senses.definition: a medical condition that some people are born with, caused by a fault with one chromosome, which results in learning disabilities
a medical condition that some people are born with, caused by a fault with one chromosome, which results in learning disabilities

examples.x: Her older brother has Down's syndrome.
Your chance of having a baby with Down's increases with age.

senses.definition: a condition affecting the brain that causes difficulty in reading and spelling, for example, but does not affect intelligence
a condition affecting the brain that causes difficulty in speaking and understanding
the act of repeating everything somebody says, as a result of a mental condition
a dog trained to guide somebody who cannot see well or at all

examples.x: These dogs have been bred to work as guide dogs for blind and visually impaired people.

senses.definition: unable to hear very well

examples.x: She is hard of hearing and her eyesight is starting to fail.
You may need to interact with deaf or hard-of-hearing co-workers or clients.

senses.definition: people who are unable to hear very well

examples.x: subtitles for the deaf and the hard of hearing

senses.definition: a small device that fits inside the ear and makes sounds louder, used by people who cannot hear well

examples.x: to have/wear a hearing aid

senses.definition: a dog trained to help a person who cannot hear well by making them aware of sounds such as the ringing of a phone or a doorbell
not working as it normally would or as it does in most people

examples.x: impaired vision/memory
Anxiety can lead to impaired cognitive function.
Since my accident I have impaired mobility.
patients with impaired renal function
The battery life of the product was seriously impaired.

senses.definition: having a particular kind of disability Disabled

examples.x: people who are visually impaired
She is now registered as severely sight-impaired but has continued to paint and create works.

senses.definition: an injury, illness or condition that means that part of your body or brain does not work as it normally would or as it does in most people Impairment

examples.x: impairment of kidney function
visual impairments
He drove in a state of serious impairment due to alcohol.
The drug is approved for mild cognitive impairment.

senses.definition: difficulty in learning and understanding things or in managing everyday activities, which affects somebody for their whole life learning difficulty

examples.x: a child with severe learning difficulties
A student may need extra support with a specific learning difficulty.
Because of my learning difficulties, I struggle to order tickets online.

senses.definition: difficulty in learning and understanding things or in managing everyday activities, which affects somebody for their whole life learning disability

examples.x: She works in a school for children with learning disabilities.
You may get extra help if your child has a learning disability.

senses.definition: the fact of having an arm, leg, hand, finger, etc. that is not shaped in the usual way

examples.x: She was born with an upper limb difference.
He has managed his limb difference deftly his whole life.

senses.definition: a language system created for people who have difficulty communicating, especially people with learning disabilities, that uses a combination of speech, hand movements and pictures

examples.x: I learned Makaton to help my son.
More than a million children and adults in the UK use Makaton signs and symbols.

senses.definition: the ability to move easily from one place, social class or job to another

examples.x: social/geographical/career mobility
The high cost of living acts as an obstacle to mobility of labour.

senses.definition: the ability to move or travel around easily

examples.x: An electric wheelchair has given her greater mobility.
mobility training for blind people

senses.definition: a type of light electric vehicle with a seat, a bar for controlling the direction in which it moves and three or more wheels, designed for people who are unable to move easily from one place to another because they are elderly, disabled, etc.
a band of coloured lights in order of their wavelengths, as seen in a rainbow and into which light may be separated

examples.x: A spectrum is formed by a ray of light passing through a prism.
Red and violet are at opposite ends of the spectrum.

senses.definition: a range of sound waves or several other types of wave

examples.x: the electromagnetic/radio/sound spectrum

senses.definition: a complete or wide range of related qualities, ideas, etc.

examples.x: a broad spectrum of interests
We shall hear views from across the political spectrum.

senses.definition: outside; beyond

examples.x: paranormal

senses.definition: similar to but not official or not fully qualified

examples.x: paramilitary
a paramedic

senses.definition: related to the Paralympic form of a sport

examples.x: He has been attending a para-sports club for the last year.
the World Para-Athletics Championships
She has recently set three new paraswimming world records.

senses.definition: a person who competes in Paralympic sports

examples.x: The coach at the club was the first to see my potential as a para-athlete.

senses.definition: a person who competes in the Paralympics
connected with the Paralympics or with somebody who competes in it
connected with the Paralympics (= an international competition for athletes who have a disability)

examples.x: Next week over six hundred Paralympic athletes will be arriving to take part in the competition.

senses.definition: an international competition for athletes who have a disability (= a physical or mental condition that makes it difficult for somebody to do some things that most other people can do) Olympic
to make somebody unable to feel or move all or part of their body

examples.x: The accident left him paralysed from the waist down.
He was partially paralysed by the fall.
paralysing heat
She stood there, paralysed with fear.

senses.definition: to prevent something from functioning normally

examples.x: The airport is still paralysed by the strike.

senses.definition: a loss of control of, and sometimes feeling in, part or most of the body, caused by disease or an injury to the nerves

examples.x: paralysis of both legs

senses.definition: the condition of being unable to move, act, function, etc.

examples.x: The strike caused total paralysis in the city.
The crisis over the constitution may lead to political paralysis.

senses.definition: paralysis (= loss of control or feeling) in the legs and lower body
having paraplegia; connected with paraplegia

examples.x: He was injured so badly that he will be paraplegic for the rest of his life.

senses.definition: not able to see well because of a visual impairment

examples.x: a society for blind and partially sighted people

senses.definition: a condition in which somebody is permanently unable to use their arms and legs
permanently unable to use your arms and legs

examples.x: A skiing accident rendered him quadriplegic.

senses.definition: a slope that joins two parts of a road, path, building, etc. when one is higher than the other

examples.x: Ramps should be provided for wheelchair users.

senses.definition: a road used for driving onto or off a major road such as a motorway or interstate

examples.x: a freeway exit ramp

senses.definition: a slope or set of steps that can be moved, used for loading a vehicle or getting on or off a plane

examples.x: a loading ramp

senses.definition: the long stage that models walk on during a fashion show

a condition in which somebody has an unusually high level of ability in a particular skill, for example in art or music, or in remembering things, but who has serious learning or social difficulties in other areas
a computer program that turns the text displayed on a screen into speech or Braille

examples.x: Creating a website compatible with screen readers is essential.

senses.definition: a dog trained to guide a blind person
special educational needs (the educational needs of children who have physical problems or difficulty learning). The official term SEND stands for ‘special educational needs and disability’. SEND

examples.x: Children with SEN must be treated fairly so they receive the support to which they are entitled.
We are seeking a dedicated and enthusiastic SEND Teacher.

senses.definition: houses or flats that are designed and built for elderly people or for people with disabilities so that they can live in the local community instead of in hospitals or care homes. Sheltered housing is usually arranged in small blocks, with a person in each block whose job is to help the people living there. The term is less often used in the US for this type of housing.

examples.x: sheltered housing for older people
The new sheltered housing project will be built close to the shops and main bus routes.

senses.definition: able to see; not blind

examples.x: the blind parents of sighted children

senses.definition: able to see in the way mentioned

examples.x: partially sighted
short-sighted
long-sighted

senses.definition: a language that uses hand movements to communicate rather than spoken words, as used by people who cannot hear

examples.x: They communicate in sign language.

senses.definition: particular educational needs that a child has because of a learning problem or disability Special needs

examples.x: She teaches children with special needs.

senses.definition: a serious medical condition that some people are born with, affecting the spine and often causing paralysis (= loss of control or feeling) in the legs spine
a person who walks, usually for pleasure or exercise

examples.x: The coastal path is a popular route for walkers.

senses.definition: a person who walks fast, slow, etc.
a metal frame that people use to support them when they are walking, for example people who are old or who have a problem with their legs

examples.x: He now needs a walker to get around.

senses.definition: a frame with wheels and a harness that enables a baby to walk around a room, supported by the frame
a metal frame that people use to support them when they are walking, for example people who are old or who have a problem with their legs

examples.x: He now needs a walking frame to get around.

senses.definition: a stick that you carry and use as a support when you are walking
a special chair with wheels, used by people who cannot walk because of illness, an accident, etc. uses a wheelchair

examples.x: In town, she gets about by wheelchair.
It can be hard to get around if you're in a wheelchair.
Tony manoeuvred his wheelchair out from behind his desk.
Does the hotel have wheelchair access?
better access for wheelchair users
He's been confined to a wheelchair since the accident.

senses.definition: a metal frame that people use to support them when they are walking, for example people who are old or who have a problem with their legs
